seg.input:
Gratia et pax a deo patre per Christum.
Quod me tam amice hortaris, imo urges, frater in Christo charissime, ut libellos quosdam Tertuliani [!] a te versos pellegam, non gravabor tibi morem gerere, siquidem cum tempore id fieri patiaris, nam illico non licet. Quamquam quis ego, mi frater, quem in re tanta iudicem eligis? Tu videris, quid agas, nam officium christiani hominis ego haud detrecto. Quare tibi persuade me nihil tibi denegaturum, quod vel ad tuam vel publicam christianorum omnium utilitatem prodesse sensero.
Vale.
Ex Tyguro, 15. novembris 1524.
Tuus Leo Jud.
Optimae spei adulescenti Henrico Bullingero, fratri suo in Christo charissimo.
seg.output:
Grace and peace from God the Father through Christ.
Although you urge me so kindly, indeed strongly, dear brother in Christ, to read some books of Tertullian translated by you, I will not begrudge you your favor, provided it be done in due time, for it is not allowed immediately. But who am I, my brother, whom you choose as a judge in such a matter? You must decide what you shall do, for I do not reject the duty of a Christian man. Therefore, be assured that I shall deny you nothing that I shall consider to be of benefit either to you or to the public utility of all Christians.
Farewell.
From Tyguro, 15th November 1524.
Your Leo Jud.
To the most hopeful youth Henry Bullinger, his most dear brother in Christ.
